helpers.name: reserve_function

parameters.name: file_id
parameters.description: File ID where function will be defined

helpers.purpose: Reserve function ID for naming before creation
return_statements: DATABASE CONTEXT: Creates function entry with is_reserved=1 - function not yet written in code
DATABASE CONTEXT: Returned ID MUST be embedded in function name using _idxxx suffix pattern (e.g., calculate_sum_id42)
DATABASE CONTEXT: Reserved functions excluded from interaction tracking until finalized
NEXT STEP: Write function in code with reserved ID in name: {function_name}_id{id}
NEXT STEP: After function written, call finalize_function(id, final_name, file_id, ...) to set is_reserved=0
NEXT STEP: After finalizing, call add_interaction() to track function call patterns
CHECK: Did you embed the ID in the function name correctly? Pattern is: basename_idxxx
CHECK: Does this function call other functions? Track with add_interaction() after finalization
CHECK: Is this function pure? FP analysis can determine purity_score for functional programming tracking
RELATED HELPERS: finalize_function() to complete reservation after function written in code
RELATED HELPERS: add_interaction() to track which functions call this function
RELATED HELPERS: Use get_function_by_name() or get_functions_by_file() to query after finalization
WORKFLOW: reserve_function() → write function with ID in name → finalize_function() → add_interaction()
DIRECTIVE: Used by project_reserve_finalize (sequence_order: 1) before writing code
DIRECTIVE: Used by project_file_write (sequence_order: 2) to enable rename-proof function references
DIRECTIVE FLOW: project_file_write → reserve_file() → reserve_function() batch → write code → finalize all
COMMON WORKFLOWS: Planning multiple functions → reserve_functions() for batch → write all → finalize_functions()
WARNING: Function MUST be written with ID in name - this is how function tracking works without fragile name dependencies
WARNING: Do not finalize until function actually written in file - finalize_function() will verify function exists

used_by_directives.description: Reserve function ID before writing code - AI embeds ID in function name for instant lookups (function_name_id_99)
Reserve function IDs before generating function code - enables rename-proof references

implementation_notes: Returns {success: true, id: reserved_id, is_reserved: true}
SQL: INSERT INTO functions (name, file_id, purpose, params, returns, is_reserved) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, 1) RETURNING id
Function name pattern: {name}_id{id} (e.g., calculate_sum_id42, parse_input_id15)

helpers.name: reserve_functions

parameters.name: functions
parameters.description: Array of function objects [{name, file_id, purpose, params, returns}, ...]

return_statements: DATABASE CONTEXT: Batch version of reserve_function() - atomically reserves multiple function IDs at once
DATABASE CONTEXT: All functions created with is_reserved=1 - more efficient than multiple reserve_function() calls
NEXT STEP: Write all functions with their reserved IDs embedded in names using _idxxx pattern
NEXT STEP: After all functions written, call finalize_functions() with batch of function metadata objects
CHECK: IDs returned in same order as functions array - map IDs back to function objects correctly
CHECK: Are all functions in the same file? Batch operations typically used for single-file function sets
RELATED HELPERS: finalize_functions() for batch finalization after writing all functions
RELATED HELPERS: Use reserve_function() for single function operations instead of batch with one element
WORKFLOW: reserve_functions([...]) → write all functions with IDs → finalize_functions([...]) → add_interaction() batch
DIRECTIVE CONTEXT: Not directly used by directives - utility for batch operations when creating multiple functions at once
COMMON WORKFLOWS: Large file with many functions → reserve_functions() → write all → finalize_functions()
WARNING: Batch operations are all-or-nothing - if any function reservation fails, entire operation fails
implementation_notes: Returns {success: true, ids: [id1, id2, ...]} in same order as input functions array
SQL: Multiple INSERT INTO functions ... RETURNING id (in transaction)
IDs correspond to functions array indices: functions[0] gets ids[0], functions[1] gets ids[1], etc.

helpers.name: finalize_function
return_statements: DATABASE CONTEXT: Sets is_reserved=0 after verifying function written in code
DATABASE CONTEXT: Automatically calls update_file_timestamp(file_id) to refresh parent file checksum
DATABASE CONTEXT: Function now tracked in interactions and can be queried for dependencies
NEXT STEP: Call add_interaction() to track which functions this function calls
NEXT STEP: If function operates on types, call add_types_functions() to link type-function relationships
CHECK: Did you include the _idxxx suffix in the name parameter? Must match function_id
CHECK: Is function actually written in the file? Verify it exists before finalizing
CHECK: Does this function call other functions? Track with add_interaction() for dependency graph
RELATED HELPERS: add_interaction() to track function calls (caller_id, callee_id)
RELATED HELPERS: add_types_functions() if function operates on types (factory, transformer, validator, etc.)
RELATED HELPERS: update_file_timestamp() automatically called to refresh parent file checksum
WORKFLOW: reserve_function() → write function → finalize_function() → add_interaction() → add_types_functions()
DIRECTIVE: Used by project_reserve_finalize (sequence_order: 2) after code written
DIRECTIVE: Used by project_file_write (sequence_order: 3) after successful code generation
DIRECTIVE: Used by project_update_db (sequence_order: 3) when batch finalizing new functions
DIRECTIVE FLOW: project_file_write → reserve functions → write code → finalize_function() batch → track interactions
COMMON WORKFLOWS: After finalization, function appears in dependency queries and can be referenced by other code
WARNING: Name parameter must include _idxxx suffix matching function_id - this is verified

used_by_directives.description: Finalize function after code written - sets is_reserved=false and updates file timestamp
Finalize function reservations after successful code generation
Finalize function reservations when updating database with new function metadata

implementation_notes: Returns {success: true, function_id: function_id, file_id: file_id}
Sets is_reserved=0, automatically calls update_file_timestamp(file_id)
SQL: UPDATE functions SET is_reserved=0, name=?, purpose=?, params=?, returns=? WHERE id=?
Name validation: must contain '_id{function_id}' pattern

helpers.name: finalize_functions

parameters.name: functions
parameters.description: Array of function objects [{function_id, name, file_id, purpose, params, returns}, ...]

return_statements: DATABASE CONTEXT: Batch version of finalize_function() - atomically finalizes multiple functions at once
DATABASE CONTEXT: Sets is_reserved=0 for all, calls update_file_timestamp() for each unique file_id once
NEXT STEP: After batch finalization, batch add interactions with add_interaction() for all function calls
NEXT STEP: If functions operate on types, batch call add_types_functions() to link type relationships
CHECK: All functions in array must have matching _idxxx suffixes in their names
CHECK: Are functions across multiple files? Timestamps updated efficiently per unique file_id
RELATED HELPERS: Use finalize_function() for single function operations instead of batch with one element
RELATED HELPERS: After finalizing, batch add_interaction() for all caller-callee relationships
WORKFLOW: reserve_functions() → write all → finalize_functions() → batch add_interaction() → batch add_types_functions()
DIRECTIVE CONTEXT: Not directly used by directives - utility for batch operations when creating multiple functions
COMMON WORKFLOWS: Large file with many functions → finalize_functions() → timestamp updated once per file → efficient
WARNING: Batch operation is atomic - if any validation fails, entire batch fails
implementation_notes: Returns {success: true, finalized_ids: [...]} confirming which IDs were finalized
Calls update_file_timestamp() once per unique file_id (not once per function)
SQL: Multiple UPDATE functions SET is_reserved=0 WHERE id=? (in transaction)
All operations succeed or all fail - no partial finalization

helpers.name: get_function_by_name
helpers.purpose: Get function by name (very high-frequency lookup)
return_statements: DATABASE CONTEXT: Most common function lookup - queries by name field (includes _idxxx suffix)
DATABASE CONTEXT: Returns complete function object with metadata: id, name, file_id, purpose, params, returns, purity_score, is_reserved
NEXT STEP: Use returned function_id to query interactions with get_from_project_where('interactions', {caller_id})
NEXT STEP: Check is_reserved field - if true, function still in reservation state
NEXT STEP: Use file_id to get parent file context with get_file_by_path() or get_file_by_name()
RELATED HELPERS: Use get_functions_by_file(file_id) to get all functions in same file
RELATED HELPERS: Query interactions table to see which functions this function calls or is called by
RELATED HELPERS: Query types_functions table to see which types this function operates on
DIRECTIVE CONTEXT: Not directly used by directives - utility for ad-hoc function queries by name
COMMON WORKFLOWS: Have function name from code → get_function_by_name() → extract function_id → query dependencies
COMMON WORKFLOWS: Verifying function registration: get_function_by_name() → check if null (not registered) vs object (registered)
WARNING: Name must match exactly including _idxxx suffix - partial matching not supported
implementation_notes: Returns function object or null if not found
SQL: SELECT * FROM functions WHERE name=? LIMIT 1
Returns: {id, name, file_id, purpose, params, returns, purity_score, is_reserved, created_at, updated_at}

helpers.name: get_functions_by_file

parameters.name: file_id
parameters.description: File ID to get functions for

helpers.purpose: Get all functions in a file (high-frequency)
return_statements: DATABASE CONTEXT: Returns all functions defined in specified file, ordered by creation
DATABASE CONTEXT: Each function includes complete metadata: id, name, purpose, params, returns, purity_score, is_reserved
NEXT STEP: Use function_ids to query interactions table for dependency graph within file
NEXT STEP: Check is_reserved field for each - reserved functions not yet finalized
RELATED HELPERS: After getting functions, query interactions to see call patterns between functions
RELATED HELPERS: Query types_functions to see which types these functions operate on
RELATED HELPERS: Use get_file_by_path() to get parent file metadata first if you only have path
DIRECTIVE: Used by project_file_read (sequence_order: 2) to load complete file context with functions
DIRECTIVE FLOW: project_file_read → get_file_by_path() → get_functions_by_file() → load interactions → complete context
COMMON WORKFLOWS: Working with file → get_file_by_path() → get_functions_by_file() → analyze function dependencies
COMMON WORKFLOWS: Before modifying file → get_functions_by_file() → check what functions exist → plan changes

used_by_directives.description: Load all functions for file with context - provides complete file metadata including function dependencies

implementation_notes: Returns array of function objects
SQL: SELECT * FROM functions WHERE file_id=? ORDER BY created_at
Returns empty array if file has no functions

helpers.name: update_function
return_statements: DATABASE CONTEXT: Partial update for function metadata - only updates provided fields
DATABASE CONTEXT: Automatically calls update_file_timestamp(file_id) to refresh parent file checksum
NEXT STEP: If name changed, verify _idxxx suffix still matches function_id
NEXT STEP: If params/returns changed significantly, update interactions if call signatures changed
CHECK: Did function signature change? May need to update callers if params changed
CHECK: Did name change? Code references might break unless using ID-based lookups
RELATED HELPERS: Use update_functions_for_file() for batch updates to multiple functions in same file (more efficient)
RELATED HELPERS: After updating, parent file timestamp auto-updated via update_file_timestamp()
DIRECTIVE: Used by project_update_db (sequence_order: 2) after code generation to sync metadata
DIRECTIVE FLOW: project_update_db → update_file() → update_function() batch → update_file_timestamp() final refresh
COMMON WORKFLOWS: Function refactored → update metadata → checksum refreshed → verify no conflicts
WARNING: Changing name breaks references unless using ID-based function calls
WARNING: Single function update triggers file timestamp - use update_functions_for_file() for batch efficiency

used_by_directives.description: Update function metadata after code generation - synchronizes dependencies and function information

implementation_notes: Returns {success: true, function_id: function_id, file_id: file_id}
Automatically calls update_file_timestamp(file_id) after update
SQL: UPDATE functions SET name=?, purpose=?, parameters=?, returns=? WHERE id=?
Only updates non-NULL parameters - partial updates supported

helpers.name: update_functions_for_file

parameters.name: functions
parameters.description: Array of function update objects [{function_id, name, purpose, parameters, returns}, ...]

helpers.purpose: Update multiple functions in a single file
return_statements: DATABASE CONTEXT: Batch update for multiple functions in same file - more efficient than individual update_function() calls
DATABASE CONTEXT: Calls update_file_timestamp(file_id) only ONCE at end, not once per function
NEXT STEP: After batch update, verify parent file checksum updated correctly
CHECK: Are all functions actually in the same file? file_id parameter must match all functions
RELATED HELPERS: Use update_function() for single function updates or functions across different files
RELATED HELPERS: Automatically calls update_file_timestamp() once at end - no manual call needed
DIRECTIVE: Used by project_update_db (sequence_order: 3) for batch function updates
DIRECTIVE FLOW: project_update_db → update_functions_for_file() batch → single timestamp update → efficient
COMMON WORKFLOWS: Refactored multiple functions in file → update_functions_for_file() → one timestamp refresh
WARNING: All functions must belong to specified file_id - validation will fail otherwise

used_by_directives.description: Batch update multiple functions in same file - more efficient than individual updates

implementation_notes: Returns {success: true, updated_count: count}
Calls update_file_timestamp(file_id) once at end (not per function)
SQL: Multiple UPDATE functions ... WHERE id=? (in transaction) + single timestamp update
Validates all functions belong to file_id before updating

helpers.name: update_function_file_location
helpers.purpose: Move function to different file (rarely used)
helpers.error_handling: Return error if function_id/file_ids not found
return_statements: DATABASE CONTEXT: Moves function from one file to another - updates file_id and refreshes both file timestamps
DATABASE CONTEXT: Rarely used - typically functions stay in their original files
NEXT STEP: After moving function in database, move actual function code in filesystem between files
NEXT STEP: Update any imports referencing old file location to point to new file
CHECK: Did you move the actual code in filesystem? Database change doesn't move code
CHECK: Are there interactions referencing this function? They remain valid (ID-based)
RELATED HELPERS: After moving, both old and new file timestamps updated via update_file_timestamp()
RELATED HELPERS: Interactions remain valid since they're ID-based, not name-based
DIRECTIVE CONTEXT: Not used by directives - manual operation for code refactoring
COMMON WORKFLOWS: Extract function to separate file → move in filesystem → update_function_file_location()
WARNING: Database update doesn't move code - you must manually move function code between files
WARNING: Imports will break - update all import statements referencing old file location
implementation_notes: Returns {success: true}
Calls update_file_timestamp() for both old_file_id and new_file_id
SQL: UPDATE functions SET file_id=? WHERE id=?
Not exposed as MCP tool (is_tool: false) - internal use only

helpers.name: delete_function
return_statements: DATABASE CONTEXT: Cascading delete - removes function, all interactions involving it, all type relationships
DATABASE CONTEXT: Automatically logged to notes table with reason, severity, source for audit trail
DATABASE CONTEXT: Deletes from interactions table where function is caller OR callee
CHECK: Is this function called by other functions? Those calls become broken references
CHECK: Does this function have type relationships via types_functions? They will be deleted
CHECK: Have you documented the deletion reason clearly in note_reason parameter?
NEXT STEP: Before deleting, query interactions to see what calls this function (impacts)
NEXT STEP: After deletion, remove function code from filesystem file
RELATED HELPERS: Query interactions table before deletion to preview impact
RELATED HELPERS: Query types_functions to see type relationships that will be deleted
RELATED HELPERS: After deletion, check notes table for audit log
DIRECTIVE: Used by project_file_delete (sequence_order: 2) when cascading file deletion
DIRECTIVE FLOW: project_file_delete → delete_file() → delete_function() cascade → delete interactions → remove filesystem
COMMON WORKFLOWS: Verify no critical dependencies → delete_function() → verify logged → remove from code
WARNING: Deletion is permanent and cascades to interactions and type relationships - no undo
WARNING: If other functions call this function, those calls become broken references

used_by_directives.description: Cascade delete all functions in file - automatically deletes types and interactions

implementation_notes: Returns {success: true, file_id: file_id}
Cascade deletes: DELETE FROM interactions WHERE caller_id=? OR callee_id=?, DELETE FROM types_functions WHERE function_id=?
Logs to notes: {reason: note_reason, severity: note_severity, source: note_source, type: note_type}
SQL: DELETE FROM functions WHERE id=? (after cascade cleanup)

metadata.description: Function reservation, finalization, and management operations
